history.content: My understanding is that the CA legislature/governor has requested UC admit more students (CA Residents) in exchange for an increase in state funding.

children.subject: I think the biggest thing to remember is that Cal is a public university: it has a mandate, implicit and explicit, from the state of California to educate as many californians as possible, and as cheaply as possible. The private universities you mention have significantly lower undergraduate enrollments: ~30,000 for Cal, ~7,000 for Stanford, ~4,500 for MIT. These private universities often have more land and larger endowments, but choose to accept few students.
Actually, we probably would have gotten in (4.8/8.4 = 0.57), but that's not a valid reason to expand enrollment. Our admission could very well be part of the problem.
Ah, but of the three of us on average one of us wouldn't have gotten in ;)
Probably if Berkeley accepted fewer students neither you nor I would've gotten in.
I think this is really well thought out and explained follow up.

The acceptance rate for Cal EECS has dropped if you compare it to the previous years. On the website it indicates that the acceptance rate for the 2016-2017 academic year for freshman was 6.6%. A different source indicates the percentage was 7.8% back in 2015. Additionally, not more than a decade ago, the acceptance rate for Cal EECS was roughly triple the current percentage. Regarding MIT, I think the number you provided is for their graduate program. They do not accept by major, rather you are accepted by the university, and then at the end of your first year you pick a track (major). Unless things have changed the last two years, this was the process according to a friend of mine who attended 2012-2016. The most recent data regarding their acceptance rate sits at about 7.9%. So in comparison to MIT, just going by acceptance rate, it is comparable. The number provided for Stanford was correct. 

However, even with this low acceptance rate, a large (by comparison) number of people are being admitted for two reasons: The sheer number of applicants and the requirement that Cal educate California. Using MIT again, they have close to 500 undergraduate EECS majors and Cal has nearly triple that amount. To match the numbers, Cal EECS acceptance rate would have to drop below even Stanford, and given that Cal is a public university, that is unlikely. 

With that said, given that the university has indirectly admitted to mistakes in financial management, better planning was absolutely necessary and I wholeheartedly agree. It is important to note that I am only speaking in regards to the EECS department, and by extension, EE and CS courses. Regarding overcrowding, it appears some measures have been put in place (not allowing intentional failing and raising the GPA cap for L&S). Though I could be completely off base about that. I too would like to hear an instructor's input on the matter with respect to sustainability.

history.content:
In her message today, Carol T. Christ went on to say

"The average lower division lecture size in our department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science has gone from 65 students in 2011-12 to 227 in 2016-17, the number of students taught from 7,986 to 15,470. [...] The tuition increase would enable us to address these issues of overcrowding and unmet demand for courses." (emphasis mine)

The points she makes afterwards regarding the effects of this population doubling are well-founded, but the most obvious question that strikes me is "why?"

If we can't keep up with the rate of growth, why accept more students? Why double enrollment if you can't even pay for it?

There's talk about sustainability - surely, continued and boundless growth of the student population isn't sustainable, regardless of tuition increases?

When it comes down to it, isn't this just a matter of restricting how many students can enter a major, like most other colleges seem to do? After all, if we never accepted 8k more students in the first place, we wouldn't exactly need to increase our tuition this much.

Compared to other colleges, our EECS acceptance rate is sky-high: 8.4% at Berkeley vs 6% at MIT and 4.8% at Stanford. Surely, restricting enrollment to a more reasonable level would lead to a better life for everyone involved? More funding and resources for students, less need for tuition increases, so on and so forth? Because the solution seems pretty simple: match Stanford's acceptance rate, number of students goes back to normal, we don't need to hire 50 more professors and hundreds of more TAs, and the perceived value of the degree skyrockets because of selectivity. A win-win for every student and over-burdened employee.

I'm sure I'm missing something. Just curious what it is.

I'd like instructor answers only, please, though student thoughts are welcome in follow-ups.
history.subject: Regarding tuition: Why don't we simply take less students?
